primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The movement from an anxious, competitive life of 'taking' (self-assertion) to a life of 'waiting' (receptive trust in God's generosity).

tekstueel_bewijs: We look not at what can be seen
We are readily drawn into the world of taking
Good things come to those who wait
the inner self loved by God... will flourish
the gospel is about receiving gifts from God
O Israel, hope in the LORD!
The good news interrupts the world of taking
We do not take the wine... It is given

tegenstander.identificatie: Anxious Society / Adidas Ad / The 'Taking' Mantra
tekstueel_bewijs: Taking is the mantra of the ownership class
an ad-driven society... preoccupied with how we look
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is primarily a cultural mindset and a psychological disposition (anxiety) rather than a cosmic power like Sin or Death.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical life of sharing and 'doing the will of God' as a member of Jesus' family.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The 'Hopers' (The Church)
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Shared joy and just sharing with neighbors
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: Receiving from God (Primary) enables sharing with neighbors (Secondary).

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: The Gospel → The Hearer ← Anxious Society

voorbeelden_god_subject: inner nature is being renewed [by God]
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We look not at what can be seen

voorbeelden: pay close attention to the hidden self
willing to be on the receiving end
if you want it, you need it
Paul refers to the reality of death
We hopers are empowered to a very different life

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on shifting the hearer's desire (Vouloir) from taking to waiting. It assumes that if the hearer 'knows better' (Savoir), they will choose to wait.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (Taking/Adidas) to S1 (Waiting/Psalm) via the negation of S2 (Receiving at the Table).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved at the Communion Table where 'taking' is physically impossible because the elements are 'given'.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Moderate; 'Taking' is seen as a social ill and a spiritual mistake, but not an inescapable ontological curse.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon uses the language of grace and 'receiving,' the actantial subject is frequently the human 'we' who must choose to wait rather than take. It leans toward 'Recruitment' (Vouloir).

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Get focused on what matters, and this in a world that seduces us.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: The deathliness of taking has been interrupted by the generosity of God.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Paul and the Psalmist are used as models of the 'waiting' posture.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Focus on how God's faithfulness forces the Psalmist to wait, rather than the Psalmist's virtue of patience.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Pressure to be more patient and less greedy.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Sanctification is viewed as a conscious choice of the self-aware subject.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The contrast between 'Wait' and 'Take' is consistently applied across all biblical texts.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'we make it by receiving' (passive) and 'get focused' (active).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: My only comfort... is that I belong to my faithful savior Jesus Christ.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon lacks a clear mechanism for how the hearer receives the 'power' to wait.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is described as 'anxiety' and 'self-centeredness'—dispositions that can be corrected by a change of perspective.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully identifies the 'Object' (Grace/Gift) but often keeps the 'Hearer' as the 'Subject' who must attain it through the act of waiting.

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: The hearer is the subject of 'waiting,' making waiting a new work.
subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: Make God the Subject who 'stills' the soul or 'grants' the wait.
subject_herpositionering.voorbeeld_revisie: Instead of 'We must wait,' use 'God halts our frantic taking and places us in a state of holy expectation.'

identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: Hearer as the 'Morning' (Receiver) or the 'Israel' who is redeemed.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that the sun rises regardless of the watchman's effort.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Increase Pouvoir (God's power to enable waiting).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Explicitly mention the Holy Spirit as the one who produces the fruit of patience.

tegenstander_intensivering.voorgestelde_intensivering: Connect 'taking' to the 'bondage of the will' or the 'power of Death'.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: If the opponent is just an ad, the solution is just a better mindset. If the opponent is Death, the solution must be Christ.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: The hierarchy is good: God's gift at the table leads to shared joy.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon has a beautiful central metaphor. To move from 'Mixed' to 'Grace,' ensure that 'waiting' is not presented as a human achievement but as a gift of the Spirit.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would praise the Adidas contrast; Greimas reveals this contrast still leaves the human as the primary actor.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains Psalm 130; Greimas shows how the sermon uses the Psalm to assign roles to the modern congregation.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that 'waiting' can function actantially as a 'work' if the Hearer is the Subject.

volledige_subject_lijst: Taking puts us at the center
appendices.notities: The sermon is rhetorically strong but structurally anthropocentric because 'waiting' is framed as a modal competence (Vouloir) the hearer must exercise.
